John Arrowwood wrote:

>
>I'll have to do some poking around to see if I can get away with floats 
>instead of doubles...  I'll try making a copy of one and converting all 
>'double' to 'float' and seeing if it outputs identical results.  If so, then 
>yeah, I'll change it.  But that does pose an interesting question:  if I 
>have too many digits in my generated source code, will the compiler 
>automatically reduce it to the size of a float, or will it do the math as a 
>double and then convert at the end?  How could I tell which way it chooses 
>to do it?
>
>  
>
Hi John,

In C/C++ if you write a float number as 0.1234f  (or F) then that 
explicitly defines a float. Double is the default if no suffix is 
specified. Java uses this same syntax, C# adds the 'D/d suffix for 
explicity defining a double (which is redundant I guess since double is 
again the default).

Colin.
